content.value_statement: TypeScript strict mode catches bugs at compile time that would cause runtime errors. This skill helps you configure and enforce strict type checking for safer, more reliable code.
actual_capabilities: Shows how to migrate from any to unknown types
Includes ESLint rules for TypeScript strict mode
Demonstrates type guards and null safety patterns
limitations: Does not automatically fix existing code
Requires manual implementation of type guards
Needs team buy-in for consistent usage

use_cases.title: Enforce Type Safety Standards

prompt_templates.title: Basic Strict Setup
prompt_templates.prompt: Help me set up TypeScript strict mode in my project. Show me the essential tsconfig.json settings and explain what each strict flag does.

prompt_templates.title: Any to Unknown Migration
prompt_templates.prompt: I have TypeScript code with many 'any' types. Help me migrate them to 'unknown' with proper type guards. Show before and after examples.

prompt_templates.scenario: Set up ESLint for TypeScript strict
prompt_templates.prompt: Configure ESLint to enforce TypeScript strict mode rules. Include all recommended rules and explain why each is important.

output_examples.input: Show me how to fix this TypeScript error: 'Parameter has an any type'
output: Replace 'any' with 'unknown' and add type guards
Use generics for reusable type-safe functions
Create interface/type definitions for your data structures
Implement proper type narrowing with if statements

output_examples.input: How do I configure my tsconfig.json for maximum type safety?
output: Set 'strict: true' to enable all strict checks
Add 'noUncheckedIndexedAccess: true' for safer array access
Enable 'noImplicitReturns: true' to catch missing returns
Use 'noUnusedLocals: true' to keep code clean

output_examples.input: Why should I avoid @ts-ignore in my code?
output: @ts-ignore suppresses errors without fixing the underlying issue
It creates hidden bugs that only appear at runtime
Use type guards or proper types instead
Your codebase becomes harder to maintain and refactor

best_practices: Always enable strict: true in tsconfig.json for new projects
Replace any types with unknown and implement type guards
Use type assertions sparingly and prefer type guards instead
anti_patterns: Using @ts-ignore to suppress type errors without fixing them
Casting to any to bypass type checking
Disabling strict flags to avoid fixing type issues

faq.question: Is TypeScript strict mode compatible with existing JavaScript code?
faq.answer: Yes, but you may need to add type definitions gradually. Start with strict: false and enable strict flags one by one.

faq.question: What are the performance implications of strict mode?
faq.answer: Strict mode has minimal runtime impact. Compile time may increase slightly, but the bug prevention benefits outweigh any small performance cost.

faq.question: Can I use strict mode with popular frameworks like React or Express?
faq.answer: Yes, all major frameworks support TypeScript strict mode. Many framework templates now include strict mode by default.

faq.question: How do I handle third-party libraries without type definitions?
faq.answer: Use declaration files (.d.ts) or the @types packages. For truly untyped libraries, create minimal type definitions rather than using any.

faq.question: What is the difference between strict and strictNullChecks?
faq.answer: Strict mode enables all strict flags including strictNullChecks. Individual flags allow gradual migration to full strict mode.

faq.question: Should I use unknown or generics for flexible functions?
faq.answer: Use unknown when the type is truly unknown. Use generics when you want to preserve type relationships across inputs and outputs.
